results.title: Robinson Crusoe
results.creator_credit: Leif Gram, Walter J Hucker and Air Programs International
results.brief_description: Scottish sailor, Alexander Selkirk is believed to be the inspiration behind Daniel Defoe’s famous novel. Intrigued by Selkirk’s tale of being marooned in 1704 on a Pacific island for four and a half years, Defoe called his imaginative account, ‘The Life and strange surprising adventures of Robinson Crusoe’. This adventure story is brought to life through animation that will appeal to children and adults alike.

results.title: Robin Hood Junior (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Lord Gilbert is away at the Crusades and the evil Baron has taken over Locksay Castle. Lord Gilbert’s daughter, Marion, flees the castle with the Great Seal of Locksay. The Baron wants it back but he hasn’t counted on the youthful cunning of Robin and the village children. Rated: G

results.title: Roar: Melbourne expressionism in the 1980s
results.creator_credit: Peter Wiseman, Traudi Allen and Video Education Australasia
results.brief_description: Formed in 1982, Roar Studios and the Roar group became synonymous with expressionism, abstract art and the emergence of a new group of talented young Australian artists that helped alter the future course of the teaching and exhibition of art in Australia. This was achieved through the breakdown of the stifling mores of the Australian art world of the time. Through interviews with artists from the original Roar group at a reunion exhibition at Roar 2 in the 1990s, critical discussion of the social circumstances and firm philosophies of the group as well as their key works, this program is an insightful study of one of the first artist run galleries and studios in Melbourne. It explores the experiences, international and local interests, and the diversity of artistic styles but shared influences of the artists who made it happen. It also discusses the significant impact of Roar on the facilitation of exhibitions for women and ethnic artists and on the emergence of an independent Australian art. The Roar artists profiled and interviewed include David Larwill, Pasquale Giardino, Stephen McCarthy, Jill Noble, Tony Mighell, Sarah Faulkner, Mark Howson, Peter Ferguson and Trevor Hoppen. The 26 minute documentary is followed by 20 minutes of extended viewing of stills of key artworks.

results.title: Roads to Xanadu. Part 2: Episodes 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, John Merson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Roads to Xanadu is an intriguing investigation of the dynamic interchange between East and West in the making of the modern world. Episode 3: “Dreams of Wealth and Power” investigates the different responses of China and Japan to the threat posed by Europe. Both countries recognised the need to modernise in some form, but it was the Japanese who forged ahead at such a speed that within forty years of opening their doors to the West, they were able to challenge the might of Imperial China, and even that of European colonial powers within Asia. Episode 4: “The Colour of the Cat” is the last episode of the series and it explores China’s most recent past and speculates about it’s future. Rated: G

results.title: Robin Hood [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Wolfgang Reitherman and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: This animated feature was one of the first films to be made by Disney after Walt’s death in 1967. Adapting the story of Robin Hood, in this take all the protagonists are animals - Robin is a handsome fox (very much in Errol Flynn mode), Little John is a bear and Prince John a lion. When the greedy sheriff taxes the citizens of Nottingham to the point of bankruptcy, Robin Hood, a benevolent outlaw arrives to save them all. Director Wolfgang Reithermann has created a fantastic animal kingdom in which to set the classic tale of the inhabitants of Sherwood Forest. Voices include: Peter Ustinov and Terry-Thomas, Andy Devine, Barbara Luddy, Roger Miller and Monica Evans.

results.title: Roads to Xanadu. Part 1: Episodes 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, John Merson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Roads to Xanadu is an intriguing investigation of the dynamic inter- change between East and West in the making of the modern world. Episode 1: “The Price of Harmony” dramatically re-creates the atmosphere of 13th Century China, the richest and most powerful Empire of those times. Episode 2: “The Invention of Progress” examines the interplay and conflict between Europe and the East, which began with the arrival of the Jesuit missionaries in Asia in the 16th Century.

results.title: Road to the stamping ground
results.creator_credit: David Muir, RM Arts and Nederlandse Omroep Stichting
results.brief_description: A choreographical journey with Jiri Kylian of the Netherland’s Dance Theatre into the world of dance in Indigenous Australia. The documentary which opens the program follows Kylian’s visit to the Groot Eylandt tribal dance congregation in 1986 where his dance production Stamping Ground was first conceived. In Stamping Ground Kylian sought to underline the common qualities of ballet and Aboriginal tribal dance as well as fuse the two styles into a work that comments on the universal nature of human movement as a form of cultural and personal expression. Following interviews with the Dance company performers about the piece and footage of rehearsals demonstrating movements inspired by Kylian’s time at the Groot Eylandt congregation, the second half of the program is a presentation of the final performance of Stamping Ground by the Netherlands Dance Theatre Company.

results.creator_credit: Matt Morgan, David Lowe and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A man is murdered in a swimming pool at the beach. But did anyone actually witness the event? Cast features Mary-Lou Stewart, Roy Billing, Monique Spanbrook, Greg Blandy.

results.title: Code blue
results.creator_credit: Andrew O'Sullivan, Pascal Guilloux, Moira Moss and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A busy intersection in a large city. Everyone is going about their own business - waiting to cross the road, minding their children…A jay-walker is run over by a courier van. How fast can the city heal itself? ‘Code blue’ is a tightly directed and beautifully paced film which has screened at over 20 festivals throughout the world. The film’s blue tones help to create a tense and emotive ten minute journey through a fast city.
